block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Aid Groups in Afghanistan Afghanistan is struggling to rebuild, and foreign aid groups continue to give support. There are hundreds of international nongovernment organizations registered with the Ministry of Planning, whose outgoing minister has led a personal crusade against the groups.

Judge Questions Hussein Aides The chief investigative judge for the Iraqi tribunal established to try Saddam Hussein and his top aides said that he had held a formal investigative session with two of the aides.

Continuing Violence in Iraq One Iraqi eighth grader was killed and six others wounded in Mosul when a bomb hit a school bus full of children, the military said. Insurgents also staged several attacks in north-central Iraq, killing one Iraqi and wounding several others.

Climate Conference Ends Two weeks of negotiations at a United Nations conference in Buenos Aires on climate change ended early with a weak pledge to start limited, informal talks on ways to slow down global warming, after the United States blocked efforts to begin more substantive discussions.
NATIONAL

Military Wants Spy Control The Pentagon is drawing up a plan that would give the military a more prominent role in intelligence-collection operations that have historically been the province of the Central Intelligence Agency, including missions aimed at terrorist groups and those involved in weapons proliferation, according to Defense Department officials.
The Pentagon is seeking special authority to resume administering the anthrax vaccine to military personnel, military health officials said.
More Arrests in Arson Case Three more people were arrested and charged with arson in the fires that destroyed 10 houses and damaged 16 others in a southern Maryland development.
A Prosecutor's Next Role Richard M. Romley, a Republican and a celebrated Arizona county prosecutor, is retiring, but is weighing a run for higher office.
NEW YORK/REGION
Public Schools' New Image The Department of Education plans to spend more than $1 billion over the next five years to continue converting non-traditional spaces into new schools
